passage:
In the past decade, remote work has grown from a niche concept to a widespread practice adopted by companies around the world. While technology played a significant role in enabling this transition, the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the trend by forcing businesses to adapt rapidly to remote operations.

For many employees, working from home offers flexibility and eliminates long commutes, contributing to a better work-life balance. Employers have also seen benefits, such as reduced overhead costs and access to a broader talent pool that’s no longer limited by geography.

However, remote work is not without challenges. Some employees report feelings of isolation and lack of motivation. Managers may also struggle to build trust and maintain team cohesion when their teams are spread across different locations. Communication can suffer without face-to-face interaction, and maintaining productivity requires new strategies and tools.

Despite these drawbacks, many experts believe that remote work is here to stay. Hybrid models — combining remote and office work — are becoming increasingly popular, offering a middle ground that addresses the downsides while preserving the benefits.

As companies continue to experiment and refine their approach to remote work, one thing is clear: the way we think about work, location, and productivity is evolving — and likely won’t return to what it once was.
question: What is the main idea of the text?
options: Remote work is becoming a permanent part of the work culture.
Technology has replaced all office jobs.
The pandemic ended all traditional work models.
answer: Remote work is becoming a permanent part of the work culture.
